Both positive and negative points for this game.  Pros: -Huge variety of creatures to tame, which you can ride or have run around as pets with you- most creatures are tameable, and it does tell you which ones are and are not. -The avaliable mounts look pretty awesome. -When you get all familiars in an area you can claim rewards. -Daily rewards that are actually helpful! -Don't start off as a nobody; you're a well-known warrior. -Classes are a fun challenge to learn and look cool. -Amazing graphics. -Mounted combat and normal combat are both features; generally you can choose which you want to do, although aerial mounted combat is a little more tricky. -Dungeon armour is avaliable at the auction house (albeit for exorbitant prices) thanks to other players, meaning if you don't have time or can't be bothered to grind the dungeon for ages then you can buy the armour.  Cons: -Can only create 3 characters -Repeated disconnects from servers -Teleportation costs (not too expensive, certainly, but if you go broke and can't afford it it can be a mild inconvenience, just means travelling on mountback for a while until you have enough money) -Takes ages to gather resources for certain familiars, even then not a guaranteed chance of taming. (Same as most MMOs in that sense, but it can get a little infuriating when you spend several hours getting resources to craft an item and fail the taming.) -When lag hits it hits bad and at the worst of times -Not everything in the trailers has been implemented in the game yet, although hopefully it will be eventually. -The leveling seems to get a bit wonky at some points, although that might just be my own inexperience not knowing about it. It doesn't make the main story impossible, just means it takes longer to get to the same level as the entities around you. -You CANNOT do a solo route, the game forces you to interact with other players to get good armour in dungeons. (edit; you can, as a person in the comments has thankfully added on quite kindly, if you're willing to have non-heroic gear for a while.)  The graphics are excellent, cutscenes are good and overall a good game considering it's free. Very fun.

I've been looking for a FTP MMO to scratch the WoW itch for a number of years. Having a subscription meant that I felt like I HAD to play WoW to get that money's worth, which was a big part of the addiction for me. I convinced myself (hitting rock-bottom may have had something to do with it) that cancelling my sub and waiting for WoW to go FTP was the only course of action. That was many years ago. In that time, I have played GW2, Tera, Wildstar, the Perfect World, ESO, LOTR Online, Star Trek Online, SWTOR, Aion, the list goes on. If it's an MMO, I've played it, in the hopes of filling that void that WoW left. Nothing even clame close to comparing.  Then I came across Riders of Icarus. I started a Guardian class, and I fell in love. I got the feels, the dreams of the game while I slept, waking only to think about strats and what I would accomplish in game that day. I joined a guild and met people that actually helped, and were happy to give up their time to grind dungeons with me. I began to scour wikipedia to learn as much as I could about this game, and became a wealth of knowledge to my guildmates. Finding ways to counter botters in-game, memorizing locations of rare spawns, bosses and item drops. I found ways to farm gold and crafting mats. I found ways to profit on the AH. Days went by, 3 days after the game's release, I'd amassed 36 hours of game time. I was hooked. I'd found my WoW replacement; hell, in ways it was beginning to outshine WoW. But best of all? It's free to play.   Yes, it's a Nexon game. Just don't make purchases with real currency in-game, and you won't have any issues. (It's FTP anyway, serves pay to winners right).  Yes, botters are a problem, but you can create your own channel, and specify what displays in that channel. As for bots camping spawns, the system works on first hit. The bot timers for this are good, but not perfect. Just get the first hit in through spamming your auto-attack. Changing channels also works for this most times.  Yes, the quests are mostly kill x, gather x, escort x, but at no point did I become bored, at no point did the grind become tedious.  As I've progressed through the game, I've been repeatedly impressed by the difficulty of it. I've marvelled at the beauty of the scenery around me. I've experienced little to no lag (a miracle for an Aust player) I've grown attached to Elite pets and mounts that I've sought out and tamed, I've been saddened at saying goodbye to pets and mounts that had outlived their usefulness or been made redundant by better, stronger, faster mounts, with higher HP and Energy pools.  But my journey has only just begun.   I'm moving interstate for work IRL, and the week between moving out of the house that I currently occupy and the house that I'm moving to before I can access stable internet again will be difficult to endure. But I will be back. I will return to this amazing world, and I will grow stronger. I haven't even come close to discovering all that this game has to offer, and I can only imagine the lands and content that await me when I return.   Visuals: 9.5/10  Gameplay: 8.5/10  Story: 9/10  Overall: 9/10 - It's Free to Play, what are you waiting for? Download it and see for yourself.  Gotta Tame Em' All!  *edited for grammar/spelling and a more detailed solution to botters.

Riders of Icarus is pleasant on the eyes and ears. As a new MMORPG, one of its selling points is the taming system ie. the ability to tame most of the creatures of the world and use them as mounts or companions. For the most part, it is pretty run of the mill - with kill/gather questing around a vibrant and colourful world with occasional visits to a throwaway storyline. As someone who loves checking out MMORPGs (FTP or otherwise), this doesn't phase me.  However, RoI has the misfortune of being plagued by several minor annoyances that can hamper immersion somewhat. While the combat itself works relatively well, the controls (especially mouse related) come up a bit short. For one, you cannot left-click drag the camera for some strange reason, nor does the cursor disappear when holding down RMB. Combat itself can be swapped between tab-target (traditional) mode, and action-combat mode - neither feeling 100% comfortable given traditional mode has very sticky targetting, often forcing ESC use, whilst AC-Mode isn't nearly as fluid as it should be and still feels very clicky and tab-target based. Having the option to swap between either one on a whim is a plus, though I do believe the developers really should have picked one method and refined it to perfection rather than try to cater for two.  The game can be very pleasing look at at times, yet for some reason they've opted for many low-res textures in a lot of areas that look very out of place. Sound (music especially) is inoffensive, easy on the ears and very suited to the environments and gameplay, though there are a few minor gripes here as well, such as some creatures being entirely soundless, even when hitting you, being hit by you, or dying. There are some sound-channel issues as well, such as sounds or dialogue randomly cutting out, which can be a bit jarring when it happens. The voice acting is passable, though there are some NPC's who seem to flit between voice-actors - such as the first city Stewart who randomly goes from a high pitched chap to some gruff, old voice out of the blue.  There are a lot more pros and cons to list, but the whole ordeal can be summarized like this: Given RoI is entirely free-to-play (with no noticable P2W), then give it a try if it looks appealing to you -- but don't expect perfection. I'll be eager to see how long it takes for the developers to employ patches to remedy issues within the game (if they bother at all) but thus far, it's not in terrible shape for an Open Beta.

I love this game! If you like the traditional style MMO and collecting mounts/pets, then this is the game for you. It even throws in a little action combat if you want it (though it's kinda a mix between traditional and Tera combat because you still have to tab target mobs if there is more than one in combat with you).   You can go around and tame almost everything you see and turn it into your pet that fights with you or your mount. You have to hit a button, jump on the back of the mob, and hit WASD (whichever lights up). However, just know that even if you get the buttons right, it may still fail and you'll have to try again...so you have to have good ol' RNG on your side! Some monsters require more than that, though, such as farming an item that drops from another mob or dropping off a small cliff and onto it's back.  Oh, and also... MOUNTED COMBAT!  So far, nothing game breaking in the cash shop.  Because it just released, there are a few minor bugs here and there, but I haven't come across anything that bad yet.  The devs are also updating quite a bit, which is nice, a big update it due here soon at the end of the month.   So honestly, I'm not sure why the mixed reviews, other than, yeah, the first day there was a long queue. Yes, it's a traditional-style MMO, but I personally don't find that to be a bad thing.

Alright, where to begin? After quitting WoW for a couple of years, I had looked else where in terms of genre for games. Played a few mobas, Rocket League, yadda yadda. But this game here really brought something refreshing to me. I have loved every hour of the few that I have played.  Pros: - Graphically appealing - Runs SMOOTH on a gtx 970 @ 60 FPS 1080p - Combat is fresh and fluent  - Two different combat styles (One an action RPG, the other like classic WoW) - Early game mounts (Instant with any founders pack, Level 5 for everyone else) - Easy to learn crafting - Already know the gathering/crafting skills - Easy transportation with world shrines at every local HUB - Auction Houses - Ingame currency can be obtained through quests/login rewards/achievements - ingame currency is NOT pay to win, allows buying of cosmetics and xp boosts for short periods. NOT ANY GEAR etc. - Mounts are just flat out AWESOME - Taming basic creatures is simple while more exotic mounts require certain skills/items etc.  - MOUNTS HAVE A VARIETY OF SKINS and provide certain buffs to said mount. Can interchange between skins. - Mounts can be turned into familiars - Familiars aid in combat - Mounts/Familiars can be turned into soulstones (i think thats what they are called, off the top of my head) and can be infused in wepons for bonuses. - Bonus XP for playing in a group - Guilds have levels and give rewards to all members once leveled higher.  AND much much more when I dive deeper into this game.  Cons: - Some visual bugs at times that require re-logging - Some framerate issues from time to time in detailed areas (especially with lower end PCs)  - Gold spammers (early launch, gonna happen) - Cannot report people that are in 'safety' zones, typically where the gold spammers stand, slightly annoying. - Typical MMO grind (But that's what we're lookig for in an MMO, it's all about the grind) - Questing can be stale (kill this gather that) but hey some don't mind. - One weird bug that crashes your game if you try switching region.. (fails to authenticate issue for some reason) - Other basic MMO complaints go here.....  Final input:  If you're on the fence about playing this game / and or buying it. Just do it. I was debating for weeks about whether or not i wanted to pay the 25$ for the early head start and I don't regret it one bit. And if you don't have the money, wait till it opens for free. It's deffinately worth a look and investing time into.  8/10 easily.

Two thumbs and a unicorn horn up.

For starters, I do enjoy this game, but that's not to say that there aren't quite a few major issues with it in its current state. Note that this is nowhere near a comprehensive review. This will only cover aspects of the game that stood out to me as a new player with no knowledge of the previous Korean version of this game.   Positive:   I'll start with some aspects of the game that I consider positive. First of all, the game is graphically great for the most part, though there are a few janky textures sprinkled throughout the landscape (especially rock textures.) Speaking of appearance, the aesthetic variety of tamable creatures ensures that most people will be able to find a suitable companion to travel the world with.   Beyond looks, Riders of Icarus has more going for it. The one I found most important is the flexible group size for dungeons. It's possible to play each normal dungeon in solo, duo, or full 5-man mode. For people like me who generally don't enjoy the usual toxic garbage tied to playing with strangers online, it's nice to be able to experience nearly all of the content alone or with a friend or two.  The crafting system for this game is much less grindy than in any other MMORPG I've had experience with. For example, you only need to 'master' two recipes in order to advance to the next tier. Mastering a recipe generally involves crafting about 5-10 of the same item which doesn't take much time at all really. Note that this may change once more of the game is released, as only the first two tiers of crafting are presently available.  Negative:   As is the case with many MMORPGs, its tutorial shows a level of action and engaged story that immediately evaporates as the final introductory cutscene brings you into the meat of the game. From there, players will be dropped off in a very traditional MMORPG experience with fetch/'kill 5 boars' quests. The ability to tame most monsters in the game becomes available fairly early on, but it's immediately clear that the process is dependent on a combination of your character level vs the level of the target creature along with an RNG mechanic.  Another grip I have with this game is in the way combat works. When I say that every single class is a clunky mess, I mean EVERY SINGLE CLASS is a clunky mess. You would think that a combat system based on chaining your skills together would have a very fluid transition between attacks, but for some reason this isn't the case. This issue becomes crystal clear when playing as an assassin who is required to constantly move and dodge in order to survive, but the vast majority of your skills causes you to be rooted to the ground for the duration of the combo, leading to a very quick and frustrating death. All in all, the combat in this game needs quite a bit of work.  Despite the problems in this game, I still think it's pretty solid for a beta and would recommend that anyone interested in MMORPGs try it out for a day or two.

I am overall quite happy with this game. The game delivers exactly what it advertises: the chance to tame and ride into combat on a large variety of mythical creatures. The storyline is at least as good as any other generic RPG, and I quite enjoy the combat and gameplay mechanics.  Here are the biggest pros and cons as far as I'm concerned:  Pros: Fairly immersive gameplay Engaging story Tame the mount that suits you Dragons! :) (lots of them) Good game mechanics Some really great and helpful players  Cons: The game still has some kinks to work out. One of the biggest is trying to attack or collect across the edge of a 'chunk' of the world. It can tell you it's 'Out of Range' when you're standing right on top of it, and you'll need to change your angle a bit to make it work. The amount of gold buyers has really exploded the game economy - it can be a little tricky to keep up on the AH or in-game trading if you don't buy gold (which may or may not be against the ToS). Doesn't impact actual gameplay that much. Like any other MMO, many of the players can be a bit elitist and snobbish at times. Don't hold that against the game though.   So overall I am happy to recommend this game. If you like MMOs, mounted combat, picking your mount from a wide variety of creatures, and an action-based combat system, this game is for you.

This is my first game review on steam, hopefully ill do the game and review justice. First i will say, Riders of Icarus reminds me of a Hybrid between Skyforge and World of Warcraft as far as the gameplay/graphics/simplicity (Skyforge), and the questing and beast taming (WoW). Ive seen some comparisons to Pokemon, but ive never played any of those games. Im a old fart, 40+ yrs old and didnt grow up on pokemon..  Like Skyforge, RoI has really sharp details and graphics in my opinion. Environments are nice and well done, the Capitol City is well done also. Playing on Full Graphic settings, im pulling in around 50-60 FPS with no real issues to speak. Gameplay is a nice change of pace here also. The game will give you two option to play from. Your standard MMO setting, of tabbing to your target, pressing hotkeys etc, and a Action setting (again think Skyforge), where you will have to keep your reticle on your target as you fight. The game recommends Action setting for the Melee characters (Assassin, Guardarian, Beserker) and normal setting for Casters (Priest, Wizard, maybe another class i may be forgetting lol). I have played with an Assassin, and Priest so far and i would agree with RoI on the gameplay settings as well. Last comparison ill draw to Skyforge is the simplicity of the game. I for one don't mind it, and is a plus for me. Some characters are harder to play then others ie Assassin vs Priest. My Assassin is currently lvl 21, and i've died many, many times versus my Priest who is currently lvl 18, and i've died twice. It could be that i just suck (perhaps) as an Assassin, or casters are just easier to play. Regardless, its nothing to get wrapped up about, as overall, i think the game will not be difficult for anyone to play. At least at this stage and levels of the game.  Questing is like World of Warcraft, or pretty much any typical MMO out there these days. Talk to NPC, kill X amount of creatures, gather X amount of ___, Tame this creature, etc etc. There is alot of running around and just talking to NPCs, particullary the quests in the Capitol. Speaking of taming, like in WoW, you are able to tame creatures and make them your Mounts and Pets. Unlike WoW though, any class can do it. Also, majority of the creatures in the game are tameable. They range from Flying mounts (birds, dragons) to the standard ground mounts (panthers, unicorns, turtles etc etc too many to list). When you first tame a creature, it will become a mount for you. You will also have a option to make the creature into a Pet that will aid you in combat with the use of a pet scroll. There is a limited amount of slots however for the number of pets/mounts you can have, without purchasing additional slots ~  Pros:  1. Gameplay and Combat. I personally love it, and having the option to use standard controls or action is a plus. Also, this game has Aerial Combat! You can kill stuff while flying around on your mounts with a crossbow or spear  2. Graphics. Very Detailed, nice graphics that i can run at full settings even on my 2012 purchased Alienware Aurora Desktop PC (Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-3820 CPU @ 3.60GHz, AMD Radeon HD 7800 Series, 16 gig ram . 50-60 FPS thru out.  3. Free to play ~ Not a pay to win game (yet anyways). I haven't seen any reason to have to purchase ANYTHING with real money, that you can't achieve just by playing the game. Of course, this game was just released, and that could possibly change down the road.   4. Taming. +++ Tame damn near any creature ya want, use em as mounts or pets!  5. Crafting system. Simple. I hate complex crafting systems. (Alchemy, Cookings, Jewelcrafting, Armor, Weapons, Barder). Your not limited here, You can craft all of em, you dont have to pick and choose which type of crafter you want to be.  Neutral:  1. No option to 'que' up for Dungeon Instances. There is a LFG Party Channel, but its just not as good as what ive come use to in other games.    Cons:  1. No PvP (yet). This is probably a neutral for me, as im not big into PvP aspects, but as it stands currently, i don't believe there is any type of PvP outside of duels in the game. I did hear that it was something that will be added, but that was just hearsay.  2. Spam Gold bots! Good grief, they are everywhere. This latest patch is supposed to be adding more 'channels', and you can block them, however, there are so many of em that you will be spending time adding them all, and ya are limited i believe on how many ppl you can add to your block list.   3. Content. As it stands, lvl 25 is the max. It doesnt take that long to reach 25, maybe a week of playing. I have a lvl 21, and lvl 18, with my hours played so far. Also, questing drys up around near that level as well outside of the dailies. Again, supposedly end of July there will be a cap level increase to 35.  So there ya have it. Overall, i am really enjoying this game, and definately recommend it as a game to try out. You have nothing to lose. Let me get this out of the way: This isn't a very good MMORPG.  The most glaring fault is obviously that they've capped the player progress far too early compared to the Asian versions of this game. Nexon's version basically ends where the other versions - and most other MMOs would be starting. This is a temporary issue, certainly, but for now it's a critical one.  Furthermore, the game feels incredibly dated. From the basic graphics to missing QOL features. Dungeon finder? Nope, not back here in 1998!  The gameplay  tries , very half-heartedly, to mix things up by introducing an alternative control method, but it's far from an actual action MMO. This isn't TERA, Blade & Soul, Guild Wars or 9th Continent. It's just tab-target combat using your mouse instead of the tab-button.  I also can only really speak about the PvE side of things because there literally is no PvP in here yet except for 1v1 duels on the street. So is the PvE content good then? No. It's not. You have the genre-typical quests and a handful of  very  short and easy dungeons. There's a classic trinity class-system but it's completely ignored for the group content. The 'tank' in this game is just an aggro initiator, and the role can be performed by anyone - even the wizard glass cannon. Every encounter just devolves into 'run in, gather whatever aggros and nuke it to pieces within 2 seconds'. There's something to be said for having the player feel powerful but this is going overboard. Nothing feels dangerous and there's nothing at stake so it's impossible to care.  The single raidboss encounter is no exception to this lack of interest, but at least he doesn't die fast. In fact, just the opposite. To access the fight you have to tame a series of mounts that are able to climb to increasingly high altitudes. That's fine and dandy but once inside you're faced with one of the worst bosses I've seen in an MMO. Confined to your flying mounts and the weapons that accompany them, your group will be engaging in a fight that is so drawn out that I went and took breaks several times throughout the fight - to no ill effect, I must add. The encounter is purely a test of patience as you whittle down his bodyparts, with the biggest 'challenge' being if everyone in the group brought enough stamina potions for their mounts to keep flying.  Catching monsters and turning them into pets or mounts is the most interesting aspect of the whole game, and if you have a bit of a Pokémon-mentality about it I'm sure you can get some fun out of that. Once you have a set of monsters you like though (you really just need 3 good ones; a ground mount, a flying mount and a pet that compliments your class with it's passive and/or attacks) you can pretty much ignore this whole part of the game as well.  Right now, the best thing I can say about the game is that gear drops in abundance inside the dungeons. You get a ton of it each run, so it's fast and easy to get your character set so you can move on - most likely to another game since this doesn't have anything else to do afterwards.

In the current state the game is very playable and I did not encounter any major problems. For a Beta game it works very well. Its nice to see that this is a traditional m m o game with some very nice graphics and a good diversity of enemies and mounts. There is a lot of character customizations, skins etc. Gear looks good and different when you get new sets of armor.  Loads of mounts with their own rarity and abilities and you dont have to wait hours for those rares because virtually everything respawns within minutes.  Interesting lore, I was a little less positive about the voice-acting and the game beeing very linear. And the zones, I dont like the zones, I would have loved just one big map. Cities and some outpost have vendors, quest NPC's and guards, it feels pretty empty if you are in the capitals.  There are five roles; beserker, guardian ,assassin, priest and wizard. They have all a unique set of powers and gear.   Personal update one:  There is a nice crafting system, but the loot system could be much better. As for now, its best to do instances with friends or your guild.  Server problems, with some disconnections from time to time.  Making a custom tab is nice to block those channels with all those spammers, but they should really do something about it, people may enjoy the game a bit more.  After many hours, there are a lot of griefers; you can get some mounts only with marks, those marks need materials that are often difficult to farm or very expensive. If people kill the mount you are taming ,your mark is used in the process, adding some unfortunate RNG, it can make things utterly frustrating. On the other side, ones you are skilled in making a certain mark you will be able to craft 1 item and you get 2 instead, slightly RNG based.   Conclusion:  This game is one of the worst beta games I have ever played, I tried to stay positive about it but I can't anymore. The game works fine but the way the game is exploited... Nexon... they made a lot of games, and even without knowing it myself I had a lot of games of this company already; they even made Titanfall!. So I had some good hopes.  We could also wait untill we have the full game, but with false promises, a company that barely cares about their customers, please, keep your money in your pocket and spend your time on other games that is the best advice I can give you about this game.
